title.narrative: Somalia Recurrent Cost & Reform Financing Project - Phase 3

condition.narrative: Section I.A.3 of Schedule 2 to the Financing Agreement:FGS or its FMS to select and engage within 3 months of signing theSubproject Agreements, and thereafter maintain throughout Project implementation, the services of a health technical partner toassist the EFMS in implementing sub-component 3.3. of the Project.

Section I.B. of Schedule 2 to the Financing Agreement:FGS and the EFMS to enter into a Subproject Agreements prior to the EFMsaccessing funds under Category 2 for the financing of their respective activities under the Project.

Section I.E of Schedule 2 to the Financing Agreement:FGS to entrust the OAuG with the responsibility of verifying the achievementof the PBCs on a semi-annual basis and, within 6 months of effectiveness, select and engage verification consultant(s) to assisttheOAuG with the preparation of the verification reports.

Section I.F. of Schedule 2 to the Financing Agreement:FGS to prepare on an annual basis, by no later than October 31 of each year,annual work plans and budgets covering the proposed activities for the following Fiscal year of Project implementation (annual workplan and budget for the first year to be exceptionally submitted by one month after effectiveness).

title.narrative: Improved budget transparency through public participation in budget process

baseline.value: 2019 rating on budget transparency under OBS (8 in 2018) and public participation (2 in 2018)

target.value: Improved rating under OBS on budget transparency and public participation to 18 and 6 points respectively

actual.value: It is still ongoing. Rating is not yet published

title.narrative: Students enrolled in schools that receive performance-based school grants (dis-aggregated by gender)
Schools participating in performance grant program receive annual grant in a timely manner
Community health service delivery plan funds executed in a timely manner, in line with Service Delivery Agreement (Percentage))
Consolidated fiscal reports published online by FGS Ministry of Finance
Number of FMS signing Service Delivery Transfer Agreements with FGS
Female Health Workers selected according to guidelines, trained, and actively providing services (Number)
Eligible civil servants salaries paid on time
Share of civil servants' salaries financed by government

baseline.value: Community health worker programs are small and in the early stages of being (re) established. Limited funds available to supportservice delivery at community level.

target.value: The FMS have (i) adopted annual community health service delivery plans, including infectious disease measures for FY 2023; and(ii) approved MoHs FY 2023 budgetary appropriations for community health service delivery for an amount equal to half theaggregated Allocated Amounts for PBCs #6.6.; #7.4 and #8.5.

actual.value: Community Service delivery plans were developed and approved by respective government entities

baseline.value: Limited tools to enable government to improved educational quality at school level. Limited funds available to support servicedelivery at school level.

target.value: Each FMS has (i) maintained a Perofrmance-Based School Grant policy for the financing of recurrent costs; and (ii) approvedaggregate FY 2023 budgetary appropriations for MoEs Perofrmance-Based School Grants equal to half the aggregated Allocated Amountsfor PBCs #6.6.; #7.4 and #8.5.

actual.value: Limited tools to enable government to improved educational quality at school level. Limited funds available to support servicedelivery at school level.

title.narrative: Strengthen FMS resource management systems for service delivery

baseline.value: Nascent systems for PFM in early stages of establishment. Expenditures focused on public administration and security with lowallocation and execution of funds for assigned education and health service delivery functions

target.value: The FMS have: (i) signed with FGS an updated Service Delivery Transfer Agreements (2023); and (ii) approved budgetaryappropriations for FY 2023 allocating a net aggregate budgetary increase for education and health sectors equal to the aggregatedAllocated Amounts for PBCs #6.6.; #7.4. and #8.5.

actual.value: FMS have approved budgetary appropriations for FY2020 allocating a net aggregate budgetary increase for education and health equalto the amount of respective PBCs

title.narrative: Strengthen payment process for operational expenditures

baseline.value: Payment process involves parallel manual and electronic steps, multiple approval steps are required, new PFM law not yet reflectedin business processes.

target.value: Comprehensive procedures aligned with the business process review, approved for following areas: *Planning and Budgeting *Internalcontrols * Accounting Procedures

title.narrative: Strengthen customs administration as per the customs reform action plan

baseline.value: Poor systems capacity: organizational, technology, HR and workflows to support effective and efficient customs management.

target.value: MoF has completed a simplified functional review of FGS customs to better allocate HR in customs.

actual.value: Functional specifications for the new customs IT system was developed and approved by FGS Ministry of Finance

baseline.value: Selected FMS have minimal sources of revenue, and therefore difficulty in sustaining their operations, while FGS collects tax andcustoms, partly from goods and services that are destined for delivery in FMS. FGS transfers to FMS have been made on an ad hocbasis.

target.value: FGs fiscal transfers execution rate for the 1st half of FY 2023 to FMS/BRA is equal to, or greater than, the out turn rate forFGs domestic revenues.

actual.value: During January to June 2020 US$30.7 million was transferred to FMS/BRA. This equals an outturn of 76% considering the budget ofUS$40.4 million. Domestic revenue outturn equaled 45% with the budgeted amount of US$ 234.4 and the actual collection of US$104.8million

baseline.value: While Inter-Governmental Fiscal Transfer Policy Paper has been agreed, it still requires operationalization. Current approach todistribution of funds between FGS and FMS/Benadir Regional Administration (BRA) is inequitable.

target.value: FGs FY 2023 budget provides for appropriations for FGs fiscal transfers to FMS/BRA as per an inter-governmentally agreed formula.

actual.value: The transfer policy paper was agreed and signed by all States in Augsut 2020. Its operationalization is inprogress now withdistribution of funds based on criteria is being discussed among level of governments

title.narrative: Citizen engagement in education and health

target.value: Government reports publicly on recorded community feedback in school and PHC inspection reports and its responses to it.
